title: Germany's top 25 attractions
text: Facebook Email Twitter Google+ LinkedIn Pinterest Germany's top 25 attractions The German National Tourist Board has just released statistics on the most popular attractions in the country. Coming it at no. 24 (tie): Nuremberg Christmas market. Held on the Hauptmarkt of the historic Old Town, this world-famous market features a medieval atmosphere. Join the Nation's Conversation To find out more about Facebook commenting please read the Conversation Guidelines and FAQs Germany's top 25 attractions The German National Tourist Board has just released statistics on the most popular attractions in the country. Coming it at no. 24 (tie): Nuremberg Christmas market. Held on the Hauptmarkt of the historic Old Town, this world-famous market features a medieval atmosphere. German National Tourist Board Fullscreen No. 24 (tie): Regensburg old quarter with the Cathedral district. The only example of French Gothic cathedral architecture east of the Rhine, Regensburg Cathedral has a wealth of medieval stained glass that is unparalleled in Germany. It's one of many architectural monuments that make Regensburg in Bavaria the best-preserved medieval city in Germany. German National Tourist Board No. 22 (tie): Harz National Park with Mount Brocken. Located within Germany's most northerly mountain range, the national park is a popular area for walking and skiing. German National Tourist Board Fullscreen No. 22 (tie): Old quarter of Dresden.The city is famed not only for its three major landmarks – Zwinger Palace, Semper Opera House and the Church of Our Lady – but also for Brühl Terrace and the Royal Palace, for the Elbe palaces on the Loschwitz hillside, for the exclusive villas of Blasewitz, the garden city of Hellerau and for the twelve Dresden State Art Collections. German National Tourist Board No. 20 (tie): Loreley rock in the Upper Middle Rhine Valley. Celebrated in song and shrouded in legend, the Loreley rock towers above the narrowest point of the Rhine near St. Goarshausen. German National Tourist Board Fullscreen No. 20 (tie): Island of Rügen, chalk cliffs and Prora. Rügen, in the Baltic Sea, is Germany's largest island and offers a variety of things to see and do – from seaside resorts to fishing villages, from parks, gardens and tree-lined avenues to palaces and stately homes. German National Tourist Board No. 19: Saxon Switzerland National Park with Bastei rocks and Königstein Fortress. This park features bizarre eroded rock formations dating from the Cretaceous period, a landscape that is the only one of its kind in central Europe. German National Tourist Board Fullscreen No. 17 (tie): Berchtesgaden with Eagles's Nest, Salt Mine & National Park. Berchtesgaden National Park is one of the oldest nature reserves in the Alps. Located in southern Bavaria, this region features majestic mountains, fantastic walking trails, scenic lakes and dense forests. German National Tourist Board No. 17 (tie): The Reichstag. Its glass dome by leading British architect Norman Foster has become a hugely popular attraction for visitors from far and wide. German National Tourist Board No. 15 (tie): Church of Our Lady in Dresden. Dresden's restored Church of Our Lady represents the pinnacle of Protestant ecclesiastic architecture and is a prime example of the European baroque style. German National Tourist Board No. 15 (tie): The Moselle Valley. The Moselle, Saar and Ruwer rivers twist and turn in narrow loops through countryside where the Celts and Romans first cultivated wine 2,000 years ago. German National Tourist Board No. 14: Munich Octoberfest. Held every year in September/October on the Theresienwiese grounds, the world's biggest beer festival features oompah bands, beer fresh from the barrel and plenty of good cheer. German National Tourist Board No. 13: Kaiserburg Castle, Nuremberg. This castle, where every emperor of the Holy Roman Empire lived, at least for a time, between 1050 and 1571, is one of the most important medieval imperial palaces. German National Tourist Board No. 12: Lake Königssee with painters' corner hiking trail and St. Bartholomew's Church. This region has been officially designated a climatic health resort in recognition of the high concentration of therapeutic activities and amenities on offer. German National Tourist Board Fullscreen No. 11: Nature reserves in the Black Forest. The reserves border the fertile Rhine valley to the west, and hilly meadows and farmland to the east. In between there are swathes of woodland, Germany's highest hills, medieval towns and cultural centers such as Baden-Baden and Freiburg. German National Tourist Board No. 10: The Romantic Road. Anyone visiting this route is rewarded with treasures such as stately homes, palaces of courtly splendour and romantic medieval timber-framed houses. German National Tourist Board No. 8 (tie): The Berlin Wall. From 1961 to 1989 the Berlin Wall divided the city in two. Most of this concrete structure has since been torn down, but fragments do remain a feature of the city. German National Tourist Board Fullscreen No. 8 (tie): Mount Zugspitze and Partnach Gorge in Garmisch-Partenkirchen. The Zugspitze is one of the most famous mountain peaks in the Alps. It's not only Germany's highest mountain, but also one of the most popular destinations for visitors from all over the world. German National Tourist Board No. 7: Lake Constance with Mainau Island, Lindau, Constance and Meersburg Castle. The Lake Constance region, where Germany borders Austria and Switzerland, is a holiday paradise set around one of Europe's largest lakes. German National Tourist Board No. 6: Old town of Rothenburg ob der Tauber. Rothenburg may be small, but it has a remarkable wealth of historical sights, museums, churches, abbeys and monuments. German National Tourist Board No. 5: Brandenburg Gate. As a signature attraction and symbol of German reunification, this monument represents the past and present of the German capital. German National Tourist Board No. 4: Heidelberg Castle and old quarter. The romantic ruins of Heidelberg Castle have been attracting visitors since the 19th century. German National Tourist Board No. 3: Cologne Cathedral. When this Gothic cathedral was completed in 1880, it was the tallest building in the world. German National Tourist Board No. 2: Neuschwanstein Castle. This castle in southern Bavaria is known all over the world as a symbol of idealised romantic architecture. German National Tourist Board No. 1: Europa-Park. Located in southwest Germany, Europa-Park is the biggest theme park in the German-speaking countries and one of the few that is open in winter. Find the complete list of 100 top attractions at: http://www.germany.travel/en/towns-cities-culture/top-100/germany-travel-attractions.html?et_rp=1 German National Tourist Board Like this topic?
